posts.post_content: angelsfire... the spell is a clear 5/5, not 4. There is a reason this is restricted in vintage. for a single mana, not only do you draw a card, but you get to decide which of the top 3 cards you want, as well as rearrange them to your liking. If it is late game and they are 3 lands, you can even choose to shuffle up then draw. great card.

Posted By: kroen (8/20/2009 11:41:32 AM)

posts.post_content: This card is truly an amazing work of art (in many senses, really). For one {U}, you have the opportunity to evaluate your next couple of turns, while also shortening the line towards a better draw in the process. However, from my experience when using this card, I would say that my favorite aspect of its design is the ability to shuffle your library *if you choose to*. In situations where your next three draws are unsatisfactory, you can reshuffle while still receiving the benefit of an extra card. Wonderfully, all of this is wrapped up in a card that can be played at the very start of the game, and its application is even useful during later in the game when you are hoping to draw that ‘special’ card. In my opinion, the design of this card undeniably represents “Blue” and everything that one would hope the color would stand for when playing it.
posts.html:

posts.post_content:
I didn't notice it before, but I guess this card could be better than [Brainstorm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Brainstorm) because of the shuffle. If you end up with junk on top of your deck, [Brainstorm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Brainstorm) isn't going to help you as much as this card.  
  
Of course, I still think it's better than this card, but they're both great.  
  
By the way, they're both restricted in Vintage. That's usually a sign that the card has potential for being broken.

posts.post_content: Beautiful art. The Lorwyn art was beautiful too (minus the merfolk). When I bought four of these online, I couldn't decide which one I wanted more. I just got two of each. The effect, also, is great. It replaces itself and can stack your draws for only 1 mana. Considering you can move your lands or other critical mana producers up (assuming they're in your top three), it's practically a free spell.

posts.post_content:
Personally, [Ponder](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ponder) is my favorite 1-drop draw card.  
  
I get the choice between the top three cards, and if i don't like them, i can just reshuffle, then draw (which, unless you stack your cards, is better than just putting the cards on the bottom w/ scry)  
  
[Serum Visions](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Serum Visions) doesn't allow me to choose between the 3 cards involved, and instead forces me to take the first and rearrange the next two.   
  
[Preordain](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Preordain) lets me pick, but only between the top 2, and i don't even get to reshuffle.   
  
I guess the two Scry cards are helpful in correcting the top few cards revealed (by something like [Sage Owl](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sage Owl) or [Halimar Depths](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Halimar Depths)), but then again Ponder can do the same...And also, with Scrying, i can make sure i don't have to see those cards anytime soon (unless i shuffle my deck, which with fetch lands in Standard, would actually pretty often for those that actually buy cards separately). This way, i have a... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
